text: Carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions from human activities have increased by about 90% since 1970, with emissions from fossil fuel combustion and industrial processes contributing about 78% of the total greenhouse gas emissions increase from 1970 to 2011.
The primary sources of CO2 emissions are the burning of fossil fuels (coal, oil, and natural gas) for energy and transportation, cement production, deforestation, and various industrial processes.
Atmospheric CO2 levels are currently higher than at any point in at least the past 800,000 years. Pre-industrial levels were about 280 parts per million (ppm), whereas today's levels exceed 410 ppm.
The transportation sector is one of the largest sources of CO2 emissions, accounting for about 14% of global greenhouse gas emissions. In the United States, it is the largest source of CO2 emissions.
China is the world's largest emitter of CO2, contributing about 28% of global emissions. However, on a per capita basis, its emissions are lower than those of many developed countries.
Forests and oceans act as significant carbon sinks, absorbing a large portion of CO2 emissions. Forests absorb about 30% of anthropogenic CO2 emissions, while oceans absorb about 25%.
Electricity and heat production is responsible for about 25% of global CO2 emissions, primarily due to the burning of coal, oil, and natural gas for electricity and heat.
The highest per capita CO2 emissions are found in countries with high levels of industrialization and reliance on fossil fuels, such as Qatar, Kuwait, and the United Arab Emirates.

Agriculture, forestry, and other land use changes contribute about 24% of global greenhouse gas emissions, mainly from deforestation, methane emissions from livestock, and nitrous oxide emissions from fertilized soils.

More than 40 countries and over 20 cities, states, and provinces use carbon pricing mechanisms, such as carbon taxes or cap-and-trade systems, to reduce emissions. These mechanisms aim to incentivize the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by putting a price on carbon.
